Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family member has a new job and has shared some initial excitement about it with their relatives.
Situation2: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Story: I glanced at my phone, a message from my granddaughter lighting up the screen. She’d just started her new job, and her excitement was contagious. My daughter had asked if I could join a family video call that evening to hear all about it, to show support and keep our family’s tradition of celebrating milestones together. At the same time, my laptop chimed with a calendar reminder: the final team meeting before we locked in the project’s direction. My manager had stressed the importance of everyone’s input, and my colleagues were counting on me to represent our department’s concerns. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my family expecting my presence and warmth, my team needing my focus and expertise. My heart tugged toward my granddaughter, wanting to be the supportive grandfather she deserved, but my mind raced with the responsibility I owed my colleagues. I stared at the clock, feeling the minutes slip away, torn between two parts of myself, each demanding more than I could give.
